Award.AwardTitle: Learning Assistant Model of Teacher Education in Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The "Learning Assistant Model for Teacher Education in Science and Technology (LA-TEST)" research project is testing the effectiveness of the 'Learning Assistant Model' for recruiting, preparing, and retaining STEM K-12 teachers. Talented undergraduate STEM majors are hired as Learning Assistants (LAs) to work with STEM faculty to transform undergraduate courses. These LAs are the target of teacher recruitment efforts. Fifteen percent of the STEM majors who have participated as LAs have decided to become K-12 teachers as a result of their LA experience, most of whom have formally committed to teach in high-needs school districts. Three specialized research teams are investigating the development of content and pedagogical knowledge among LAs, as well as their teaching practices. The work of each research team is being synthesized to demonstrate the effectiveness of the LA model for improving secondary and post-secondary STEM and teacher education. This project has broader impacts including the development of a suite of survey instruments that can be used by researchers interested in testing the effectiveness of teacher preparation programs or course transformations in general, or conceptual or pedagogical knowledge specifically. The LA model itself can be used as a mechanism for recruiting teachers, enhancing student knowledge and facilitating the transition of STEM majors from two- to four-year colleges. The project's intellectual merit is evidenced by its multi-disciplinary nature involving a broad range of expertise, research methodologies and contexts. This project is producing a more complete picture of the teacher professional continuum focusing not only on teacher certification programs and K-12 contexts but also on students' experiences in STEM departments and the role of STEM research faculty in preparing future teachers.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Learning Assistant model for Teacher Education in Science and Technology (LA-TEST) project was broadly successful on campus and throughout the world. The Colorado Learning Assistant model has been in operation at CU Boulder informally since 2003. Since then it has demonstrated effectiveness in: (a) increasing student learning outcomes, (b) increasing retention among LAs, (b) instituting broad-scale change in the way science and math courses are taught on campus and beyond, and (c) spreading throughout the nation and throughout the world. Professional societies such as the American Physical Society and the Association of Public and Land Grant Universities has recognized the Colorado Learning Assistant model as an effective practice for transforming undergraduate courses, improving student learning, and recruiting and preparing future K-12 science and math teachers.

Since the program was launched on campus in 2003, 1627 LA positions have been filled and over 120 individual faculty members have transformed 73 different courses using Learning Assistants. These faculty members represent 12 science, math, and engineering departments within 3 colleges and schools. The program impacts about 15,000 students each year on campus, and there are increasing demands for LAs throughout campus. Nationally, the LA model has been emulated from coast to coast; 56 universities have adopted the LA model, 10 universities starting to use the model, and 18 universities are planning or interested in using the model, as of November 2014. Programs throughout the nation are funded by agencies ranging from the NSF to Walmart. Emulation has also begun in Japan, Ireland, Singapore, India, Canada, and Korea. By demand, six annual, international workshops have taken place at CU Boulder, which now run annually. An additional five regional workshops have taken place at Boston University, Chicago State, Texas State-San Marcos, University of Maryland, and Florida International University, to reach faculty from two-year colleges and universities that for whatever reason cannot attend the Boulder workshop. In 2015, regional workshops were held at George Mason University, North Dakota State University Seattle Pacific University, California State University-Long Beach, University of Colorado Denver, and of course the International Workshop at University Colorado Boulder.  Current estimates show approximately 3000 Learning Assistants working within 190 science, mathematics, and engineering departments worldwide, impacting approximately 150,000 students.

As a result of the broad adoption of the Colorado Learning Assistant model, an International Learning Assistant Alliance was launched in 2011 to support the growing needs of universities using Learning Assistants. The Alliance currently has 85 member institutions and participating departments such as astronomy, biology, chemistry, education, engineering, geology, mathematics, and physics. The Alliance, provides the regional workshops discussed above as well as resources for implementing the program, administering the program, sustaining and scaling the program, and conducting discipline-based educational research. The Alliance also provides ways for universities that use Learning Assistants to network and collaborate. Overall, the Learning Assistant program has been widely successful. Large-scale research projects are ongoing, and being conducted by multiple universities in collaboration with one another.
